questionnaire.description: The company coach is your main entry point to proceed on the Fast-RampUp track. It gathers some information about your company, such as employee count and a couple of technical questions (e.g., which operating systems you use within your company). With this information, the coach can ask you the questions that are relevant for your profile and give the recommendations that benefit you the most.

question.text: How many employees does your company have approximately?

instruction.text:
Configure the company size by defining the number of employees. You can adapt the number, for example as your company grows.

 

The size of the company affects your needs for cybersecurity practices. For example, a medium-sized company will benefit from company-internal cybersecurity expertise and dedicated budgeting. A small company benefits more from outsourcing of such specialty expertise. CYSEC will adapt its recommendations accordingly.

Document the headcount (number of people) and not the full-time-equivalent. For example, a company with 10 employee working with a 60% contract should state 10 and not 6. Also, do count special roles such as the CEO as an employee.

question.text: Do you want to instantiate subcoach backup?

instruction.text:
Configure the company size by defining the number of employees. You can adapt the number, for example as your company grows.

 

The size of the company affects your needs for cybersecurity practices. For example, a medium-sized company will benefit from company-internal cybersecurity expertise and dedicated budgeting. A small company benefits more from outsourcing of such specialty expertise. CYSEC will adapt its recommendations accordingly.

Document the headcount (number of people) and not the full-time-equivalent. For example, a company with 10 employee working with a 60% contract should state 10 and not 6. Also, do count special roles such as the CEO as an employee.

question.text: Do you want to instantiate subcoach patch management?
Do you want to instantiate subcoach malware?
Does your company have a company-internal IT department?

option.comment: Good. This is an asset for your cyber defense. We recommend you to employ some staff with cybersecurity expertise.
We recommend you to discuss cybersecurity with your IT service provider. Approach the SMESEC team if you would like to obtain guidance.

instruction.text:
State whether you have a dedicated group of employees who are responsible for your company’s IT.

 

Know your limits. A company without own IT expertise benefits from external experts who offer cybersecurity expertise. CYSEC will indicate when it is safe for your company to do things yourself and when it safer to seek external help.

An IT department provides essential services for ensuring a company's vitality. The IT department is not just responsible for the networks and servers, but also for cybersecurity.

When your company is attacked, the IT department leads emergency management. The IT department delivers robust cybersecurity by should taking direction in how your company responds to cyber-attacks. The IT team members should be alert and aware at all times of possible threats and have the cybersecurity plan that includes the practices you find in the coaches of the CYSEC tool.

Activate coach for Malware Scans ...

Your company’s cyber-security knowledge will be concentrated within the IT department. The IT department defines and maintains your company’s approach and your employees' training in cybersecurity. Everybody must be aware of how their online behaviourputs both themselves and their work environment at risk. The IT department knows the cyber-attacks the company is exposed to and the tactics that hackers use. By providing the company’s employees with training, e.g. where actual attacks can be experienced in the company's real-life scenarios, the IT department can keep the business secure.

Activate coach for End-user Training ...

question.text: Does your company have a "CISO"?

option.comment: Good. This is an asset for your cyber defense.

You should have a person responsible for cybersecurity in your company, even if you work with an external service provider. Discuss this in your company and return to this question once you have a CISO.

instruction.text:
Appoint an employee to be your “Chief Information Security Officer” (CISO). This employee should be responsible for cybersecurity in your company, empowered by the CEO, and accountable for the cybersecurity tools, training, culture and incidents that may happen.

 

The CISO is the main user of the CYSEC tool.

It is only through a dedicated person that your company can address cybersecurity holistically. Spreading responsibility among multiple employees would lead to hidden assumptions and misunderstandings that could lead to easily avoidable incidents.

A CISO is a senior-level executive within an organization and should have a good knowledge of both the company’s business as well as technology knowledge. The CISO may be supported by other employees for implementing and maintaining cybersecurity in the company.

The CISO’s responsibilities are as follows:

  • Establish and maintain the strategy for protecting the company’s data and technology.
  • Identify, develop, implement, and maintain cybersecurity practices, e.g. based on the CYSEC recommendations.
  • Respond to incidents, establish standards and controls, manage cybersecurity technologies, direct the implementation of policies and procedures.
  • Responsible for information-related compliance and certification (such as ISO/IEC 27001).
Cisohandbook.com

question.text: Is the CISO experienced?

option.comment: Good. This is an asset for your cyber defense.
Consider training your CISO. There may be courses nearby (see accompanying text). Approach the SMESEC team if you would like to obtain guidance.

instruction.text:
State here whether the CISO is experienced in the role of the CISO.

 

The person most experienced in cybersecurity in your company should be the CISO. The CISO is accountable for decisions related to cybersecurity and coordinates those who help to protect the company.

 

There are several educations and certifications for which an inexperienced person may enrol, including the following ones:

Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP). Earning the CISSP shows that you are able to design, implement and manage a cybersecurity program for a company. The CISSP focuses on security and risk management, assessment, testing, and operations.

More info ...

 

Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH). A Certified Ethical Hacker is a professional who understands how to look for vulnerabilities in target systems. The CEH focuses on the latest malware attacks, the latest hacking tools, and new emerging types of attacks in the cyberspace.

More info ...

 

You may approach the SMESEC team for recommendations about a local CISO service provider.

More info ...

question.text: Where is your company located?

option.comment: The GDPR rules apply for you. Study them and discuss in your company of what you will do about them.

option.text: A PLACE WHERE EU LAW APPLIES
option.comment: The GDPR rules apply for you. Study them and discuss in your company of what you will do about them.
The GDPR rules apply for you in some circumstances. See next question.

instruction.text:
State whether your company is located in the European Union (EU), respectively a place where EU law applies.

 

The European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) applies for any company that is located in the European Union and controls or processes personal data.

 

The EU member states are as of April 15, 2019: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czechia, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and United Kingdom. The EU member states are evolving. The United Kingdom is in the process of leaving the EU. Albania, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo are candidates or potential candidates to join the EU.

More info ...

 

The GDPR regulation can be accessed on the Internet. The article 3 describes where, respectively under which circumstances the GDPR is applicable.

More info ...

question.text: Do you process data about people located at the following places?

option.comment: The GDPR rules apply for you. Study them and discuss in your company of what you will do about them.
The GDPR rules apply for you only if indicated so in the previous question.
The GDPR rules apply for you. Study them and discuss in your company of what you will do about them.

instruction.text:
State whether your company controls or processes personal data monitors the behaviour of people located in the European Union (EU).

 

The European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) applies for any company that is located in the European Union and controls or processes personal data.

 

The EU member states are as of April 15, 2019: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czechia, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, and United Kingdom. The EU member states are evolving. The United Kingdom is in the process of leaving the EU. Albania, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, Turkey, Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo are candidates or potential candidates to join the EU.

More info ...

 

The GDPR regulation can be accessed on the Internet. The article 3 describes where, respectively under which circumstances the GDPR is applicable.

More info ...

question.text: Did your company designate an experienced data protection officer?

option.comment: Good. This is an asset for your GDPR compliance.
Good. Return to this question regularly to check whether your conditions have changed.
You should have an experienced data protection officer, either employed or outsourced. Discuss this in your company and return to this question once you have a CISO.

instruction.text:
Appoint an experienced data protection officer: a person responsible for the company’s proper conduct in processing sensitive data.

 

The European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) requires a data protection officer to be designated in some circumstances:

  • Conditions (article 37): when data subjects are systematically monitored on a large scale or when the following special categories of data are processed: racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, genetic data, biometric data, health data, or data about sex life or sexual orientation.
  • Tasks (article 39): to assess the impact of data protection, to advise those who process data, to monitor compliance with the GDPR, and to cooperate with the authorities.

More info ...

 

You may approach the SMESEC team for recommendations about a local Data Protection Officer service provider.

More info ...

question.text: Does your company have a “CSIRT”?

option.text: YES, WITH THREE OR MORE MEMBERS
option.comment: Good. This is an asset for your cyber defense.

option.text: YES, WITH ONE OR TWO MEMBERS
option.comment: Good. This is an asset for your cyber defense. You can increase the availability and robustness of the CSIRT by adding members.
Think about what you will do when you are being attacked. Without a CSIRT, you will have nobody that responds. Discuss this in your company and return to this question.

instruction.text:
Appoint an experienced “cyber security incident response team” (CSIRT) that responds to security breaches, viruses, and other potentially catastrophic incidents.

 

Companies have responsibilities to their members and stakeholders as well as to the public. This responsibility extends to “doing the right thing when things go wrong.”

 

The CSIRT should be available 24 hours per day and 7 days per week with the following responsibilities:

  • Prepare for and detect security events.
  • Respond to security breaches, viruses, and other potentially catastrophic incidents.
  • Guide the company’s executives and public-relations on appropriate communication.

More info ...

question.text: Is the CSIRT trained and experienced?

option.comment: Good. This is an asset for your cyber defense.
Consider training your CSIRT. There may be courses nearby (see accompanying text). Approach the SMESEC team if you would like to obtain guidance.

instruction.text:
The incident coordinator should be experienced in handling cyber incidents. The other members of the CSIRT should be trained for effectively assisting the incident coordinator.

For the incident coordinator, there are several educations and certifications for which an inexperienced person may enrol, including the following ones:

  • Certified Information Systems Security Professional (CISSP). Earning the CISSP shows that you are able to design, implement and manage a cybersecurity program for a company. The CISSP focuses on security and risk management, assessment, testing, and operations.

More info ...

  • Certified Ethical Hacker (CEH). A Certified Ethical Hacker is a professional who understands how to look for vulnerabilities in target systems. The CEH focuses on the latest malware attacks, the latest hacking tools, and new emerging types of attacks in the cyberspace.

More info ...

You may approach the SMESEC team for recommendations about a local CSIRT service provider.

More info ...

The other members of the CSIRT should have passed at least the end-user training. If you select “NO” here,  CYSEC will recommend that training.

question.text: Do you provide of the following digital offerings for customers?

option.comment: SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your software
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your devices.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your networks and servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your customers’ networks, clients, and servers.
Check: do you really have no homepage? That would be an example of an SaaS. If outsourced, talk with your provider about how to protect it.

instruction.text:
Describe any digital offerings of your company.

 

Companies with digital offerings have more cybersecurity needs than companies that do business without software. For example, a software-developing company needs to ensure that the software-based products released to customers are secure. CYSEC adapts the coaches the relevant types of businesses.

CYSEC differentiates the following types of digital offerings:

  • Software: your company develops code for customers or as part of products or services offered to a market.
  • Hardware: your company engineers and produces hardware, embedded systems (cyber-physical systems, CPS), or Internet-of-things devices (IoT).
  • X-as-a-Service (Everything-as-a-service, XaaS): your company offer software usually accessed through a web-browser (SaaS), platforms allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications (PaaS), or infrastructures such as computational resources or storage (IaaS).
  • System integration: your company integrates software or components from various vendors into a system for a specific customer.
  • IT Services: your company operates an integrated information system for a customer.

question.text: Which of the following operating systems are in use on your employees’ machines?

option.comment: SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your employees’ machines.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your employees’ machines.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your employees’ machines.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your employees’ machines.
Approach the SMESEC team to obtain expert tips for how to protect your employees’ machines.

instruction.text:
State which operating systems are used on your employees’ machines.

 

Operating systems work in diverse ways and, as a consequence, require different ways of protection. CYSEC will adapt the questions to the operating systems that are in use in your company.

question.text: Which of the following operating systems are in use on your company’s servers?

option.comment: SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
If your servers are outsourced, talk with your provider about how to protect them.

instruction.text:
State which operating systems are used on your server machines.

 

Operating systems work in diverse ways and, as a consequence, require different ways of protection. CYSEC will adapt the questions to the operating systems that are in use in your company.

question.text: How many Windows servers do you have approximately?

instruction.text:
State how many Windows servers you have approximately. Count both, physical and virtual servers.

 

The number of servers affects your cybersecurity economy. For example, starting from 30 Windows servers, automated patching will be of value for your organisations.

The more servers you have, the more it makes sense to use company-internal patch servers and save network bandwidth for patching. Also, you will benefit from an environment to test patches before they are deployed on operational servers.

CYSEC will adapt the recommendations accordingly.

question.text: How many Linux servers do you have approximately?

instruction.text:
State how many Linux servers you have approximately. Count both, physical and virtual servers.

 

The number of servers affects your cybersecurity economy. For example, starting from 70 Linux servers, automated patching will be of value for your organisations.

The more servers you have, the more it makes sense to use company-internal patch servers and save network bandwidth for patching. Also, you will benefit from an environment to test patches before they are deployed on operational servers.

CYSEC will adapt the recommendations accordingly.

question.text: Is at least one server Internet-facing?

option.comment: Internet-facing servers are a higher risk, thus need particular attention.
Even company-internal servers may suffer under an attack or incident.

instruction.text:
State whether at least one of your servers can be contacted from the Internet.

 

Internet-facing servers are a higher risk for the company than servers that are only accessible from within the company’s network. For example, the Internet-facing servers are exposed to automated attacks that hackers can run with little cost and effort. These server require greater care for protection than the internal ones.

question.text: Do you provide services for your customers with your servers?

option.comment: Your servers should be redundant, and your CSIRT should monitor them continuous and react immediately in the case of an incident. SMESEC gives you tools.
Your CSIRT should monitor your servers continuously and react immediately in the case of an incident. SMESEC gives you tools.
Your CSIRT should monitor your servers continuously and prepare to react fast in the case of an incident. SMESEC gives you tools.
See that you can manually restore and start your server. SMESEC gives you tools.

instruction.text:
State the availability that you promise to your customers with your servers. Select the highest one, and consider also those services you host on Clouds like Amazon, Microsoft, or Google. Even when on Amazon or Google (you are still responsible for CIRT here).

The availability your promise to your customers with your service level agreement affects the availability requirements for your CSIRT. CYSEC will adapt the relevant recommendations accordingly.

The following table shows you for how long time a service may be unavailable per year.

  • 99.99% (“four nines”): 52 minutes, 35.7 seconds
  • 99.9% (“three nines”): 8 hours 45 minutes, 57 seconds
  • 99%: 3 days 15 hours 39 minutes 29.5 seconds
  • 90%: 5 weeks 1 day 12 hours 34 minutes 55.2 seconds

More info ...

question.text: Which of the following Internet-facing functions do your servers provide?

option.comment: SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.

instruction.text:
State the functions that your servers provide through the Internet.

 

Servers are targets for attacks and can provide opportunities for cybersecurity:

  • Web server serve content that has to be protected.
  • Proxy servers control traffic, hence are an opportunity to fight malware.

CYSEC will adapt its recommendations based on the type of servers you have.

question.text: Which of the following other functions do your servers provide?

option.comment: SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
SMESEC has specialised tools helping you to protect your servers.
Approach the SMESEC team to obtain expert tips for how to protect your servers.

instruction.text:
State the functions that your servers provide. The servers do not necessarily need be Internet-facing.

Servers are targets for attacks:

  • File servers may be a store of malware
  • Active directory contains valuable, even personal data
  • DNS servers manage directories of server addresses
  • E-mails are a target for phishing, distributing malware, and opportunities for spam.

CYSEC will adapt its recommendations based on the type of servers you have.

option.comment: Internet-facing servers are a higher risk, thus need particular attention.
Even company-internal servers may suffer under an attack or incident.

Internet-facing servers are a higher risk for the company than servers that are only accessible from within the company’s network. question.text: Have you answered all questions truthfully and to the best of your knowledge?

instruction.text:
You have gone through the company topics covered by this questionnaire. You have learned about several recommended good practices.

 

You can always start the questionnaire again. Go back to the explanations, videos, and links provided with each question to find out how to even further improve.

 

Return to the dashboard to see the recommendations we have prepared for you.
Test
